Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Seismic Study of the Galicia S Detachment
Award.AbstractNarration: Ocean basins such as the Atlantic are the end products of a process that begins with continental rifts such as East Africa, passes through a young ocean basin phase thought to be typified by the modern Red Sea, and ends with a broader ocean basin produced over many millions of years by seafloor spreading ? a process by which new ocean floor is created by magmatic and tectonic processes at mid-ocean ridges. Though the process is understood in an general way, the details of its earliest stages are poorly known because the geologic evidence is obscured by overlying sediments, massive volcanism associated with early rifting, and, in most places, thick deposits of salt. Located in the eastern North Atlantic, Galicia, is an exception, where rifting occurred with little volcanism, and there is no overlying salt. For that reason, it is an ideal locality for a strong international team to carry out this three-dimensional seismic reflection survey to image the early-formed geologic structure. Among the many broader impacts of this project are its strong international collaboration, participation by undergraduate students as well as a graduate student and a post-doctoral fellow, and the contribution of important new data to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rifted continental margins form when continents break apart to form new ocean basins. These settings are also important to understand because they are often densely populated (e.g., east coast of the US), and they host a variety of geohazards, diverse biogeochemical communities, exchanges between the oceans and solid earth, and much of the world’s remaining hydrocarbons. This project involved the collection and analysis of a 3D seismic reflection dataset offshore Spain and Portugal to study the formation and evolution of a continental margin created during the opening of the Atlantic Ocean basin.  These data provide spectacular images of major geological features below the seafloor, including a major fault that facilitated continental breakup.  With these data, we could figure out the properties of the fault, the timing and direction of slip along the fault and how it relates to other smaller faults.  These results can be applied to understand other similar faults worldwide.  Seismic data also imaged sediments deposited on the margin during and after continental breakup, which show that fault blocks formed during rifting ~120 million years ago still control the way that sediments are transported and deposited along the margin. They also show the locations of past slope failures, an important hazard on rifted margins.   In addition to these scientific results, this project also enabled training of graduate students, public outreach and strengthening of international collaborations with England and Germany.
